Operation of Fluidized-Bed Boilers
The growth rate of electric power demand in the U.S. 
has slowed considerably. Thus, the need for new, large 
utility-operated units has decreased. Coupled with 
environmental regulations, it has become economically 
feasible to use lower capacity fluidized-bed boilers to meet 
small localized increases in process steam and electrical 
power needs.
Chapter 17 provides a detailed discussion of fluidized-
bed combustion systems. The following sections describe 
general fluidized-bed boiler operation, both circulating 
fluidized-bed (CFB) systems and bubbling fluidized-bed 
(BFB) systems.
CFB systems overview
The CFB is constructed and performs similar to a 
conventional drum boiler. However, thermal performance, 
combustion efficiency, furnace absorption pattern and SO2 
control are strongly influenced by the mass of solids in the 
bed (inventory), the size distribution of the bed material 
(bed sizing), and the circulating rate of the bed (flow rate). 
Bulk bed density is a measure of the material weight per 
unit volume. There is a higher density and inventory in 
the lower furnace, made of coarser particles (average size 
200 to 400 micron), and a lower density and inventory in 
the upper furnace (also called furnace shaft) made of finer 
particles (average size 100 to 200 micron). Fig. 5 shows 
the density of the bed with respect to furnace height and 
indicates the effect of load.
To integrate these influences into operating proce­
dures, the CFB is equipped with additional instrumenta­
tion which provides operator input for bed management. 
These inputs are as follows:
1.	 	Primary zone ∆P — The gas-side differential pressure 
is measured across the primary furnace zone [from the 
air distribution grid to an intermediate elevation of 
about 7 ft (2.1 m) above the grid] and is an indication 
of the coarser bed inventory. This variable is managed 
by controlling the bed drain flow.
2.	 	Shaft ∆P — The furnace shaft ∆P, from the intermedi­
ate elevation to the furnace roof, indicates the shaft 
bed density and is managed to follow boiler load with 
corrections for primary zone temperature control. It is 
influenced by the multi-cyclone dust collector (MDC) 
recycle rate, the primary to secondary air split, and 
excess air setting.
3.	 	Lower bed (or primary zone) temperature — The lower 
bed temperature is set by the operator as a primary 
control variable for optimal combustion and emission 
performance. The shaft ∆P, primary to secondary air 
split, and excess air controls are used to control this 
operating parameter.
These variables are typically not available on pulver­
ized coal-fired boilers. However, the overall operation is 
similar. Fuel feed is set by steam requirements, total air 
flow is adjusted to follow fuel flow, and excess air is set 
to optimize combustion and unit efficiency. Shaft bed 
density is then predominantly used to control the lower 
bed temperature, the most important variable on a CFB 
boiler. The lower bed temperature is usually controlled 
to a fuel-dependent set temperature [for example 1550F 
(843C) for lignite and 1620F (882C) for petroleum coke] 
which results in optimal combustion efficiency and SO2 
absorption. The optimum bed operating temperature 
from combustion and emission standpoints is from 1500 
to 1650F (816 to 899C), depending on the fuel.
Another variable that is controlled somewhat differ­
ently in a CFB is the air admission to the furnace. The 
total air flow is divided into primary and secondary 
flows. Because total air flow is based on fuel flow, the 
primary to secondary air split becomes another important 
parameter affecting emissions and bed temperature. The 
split affects the lower bed density, shaft density, and 
control of the primary zone temperature. The optimum 
air split is determined as a function of steam flow during 
commissioning tests. Once the optimum primary to 
secondary air split (as a function of steam flow) has been 
determined for automated control, the operator should not 
need to independently manipulate the split.
Solids management is also unique to CFBs. Once the 
bed material inventory has been established, bed inven­
tory is maintained by the fuel ash and sorbent-derived

Fuel sizing and fuel characteristics
Coal firing  Fuel sizing is very important to successful 
boiler operation. It impacts the furnace heat release 
profile; fine particles tend to burn higher in the furnace 
shaft while coarse particles burn predominantly in the 
primary zone. For medium and high ash fuels, fuel sizing 
also impacts sizing of bed particles and, correspondingly, 
bottom ash to flyash split. When fuel variation occurs, 
the operator should be thoroughly trained on the required 
adjustments if the variations are outside the range of the 
programmed control logics. 
Biomass firing  Biomass fuels provide a particular 
challenge in CFB operations because of continuous 
variations in size, shape, moisture content, and heating 
characteristics. To minimize operating problems, fuel 
sources should be continuously blended to achieve the 
most uniform consistency possible. This usually takes 
place in the fuel storage area where the fuel is introduced 
to the system. Different fuel types should be stored 
separately so the fuels can be blended at varying rates 
to control furnace combustion performance. Modest 
inventories are needed—large enough to permit blending 
for uniformity of feed but not large enough to result in 
excessive inventory storage times. Bed material sizing 
should be checked on a regular basis to ensure that the 
bed material is not deteriorating. Care must be taken 
in such sampling procedures because of the high bed 
material temperature.
Startup and shutdown considerations  Chapter 
17 provides general guidelines for the startup of CFBs. 
Hot and cold startup conditions are distinguished by the 
temperature of the furnace solids inventory, either higher 
or lower than the auto-ignition temperature of the main 
fuel established at the end of the boiler purge sequence. 
As with any boiler, prior to startup and after shutdown 
the unit must be purged according to the latest applicable 
NFPA Codes. An important part of a cold startup is the 
warming of the bed material with auxiliary fuel overbed 
burners designed for this purpose. During normal 
operation, a CFB is loaded with enough bed material to 
provide a 20 in. wg (5 kPa) pressure differential across the 
primary zone. During the warming process, bed materials 
are introduced to raise the bed pressure drop from 5 in. 
wg (1.25 kPa). Auxiliary fuel is used to increase and 
stabilize the primary zone temperature at about 1000F 
(538C) in preparation for main fuel introduction. This 
temperature varies somewhat depending on the main 
fuel. Simultaneously, the boiler metal temperatures as 
indicated by steam pressure (saturation temperature) 
must be within the heatup rate allowed for the boiler pres­
sure parts. Upon ignition of the auxiliary fuel, the flue gas 
temperature entering the U-beams and the steam-cooled 
surfaces must be monitored and maintained below 950F 
(510C) until 10% of the MCR steam flow is established 
through the steam-cooled circuits. Once the primary zone 
temperature is stabilized at the fuel auto-ignition point, 
the main fuel is introduced and the bed temperature 
can be gradually raised to about 1500F (816C) where 
the auxiliary burner may be shut off. Boiler load can be 
increased from this low load operation with circulating 
mode being established with increasing solids, fuel and 
air flow. The rate of increase must be controlled such that 
the bed temperature remains stable. Primary air to total 
air ratio is further adjusted to improve combustion and 
reduce emissions.
Overbed burners are used to assist with the vola­
tilization of unburned carbon particles in the primary 
zone of the furnace. If the boiler is being shut down for 
maintenance and personnel entry into the boiler setting is 
required, then the fuel entering the bed should be stopped. 
All the carbon in the bed should be burned out for safety 
reasons. Then all solids must be completely removed from 
the boiler and hoppers, and the boiler temperature must 
be below 120F (49C) prior to entry. (See Personnel safety 
discussed earlier.)
BFB systems overview
Like its CFB counterpart, bed management of a BFB 
is important. Bed inventory, bed sizing, makeup and 
drainage must be integrated into operating procedures 
from data collected during commissioning tests. The 
BFB is also equipped with additional instrumentation 
to assist the operator in developing the unit-specific 
operating guidelines.
1.	 	Primary zone ∆P — the gas-side differential pressure 
is used as an indication of bed height. The primary 
zone may be compartmented on the air side for coal 
firing, and multiple ∆P cells are then displayed.
2.	 	Bed temperature — the typical bed temperature 
operating range is 1400 to 1600F (760 to 871C) and 
is a primary control variable. Because the control of 
this variable is critical, multiple thermocouples are 
installed in the bed and are averaged and compared 
to a bed temperature set point.
The operation of a BFB is similar to that of other 
combustion technologies in that fuel and air demands are 
set by the required steaming conditions. Bed temperature 
is controlled within the desired range by adjusting the 
ratio of flue gas recirculation (FGR) to pure air flow 
splits for biomass firing. This same procedure is used 
for coal firing (see Chapter 17) in addition to taking 
compartments of the bed into and out of service based on 
load demand (slumping). If a sorbent is used in the bed for 
SO2 control, it is usually metered in proportion to the fuel 
flow. Various interactions can occur when manipulating

or bed air at a given load increases bed turbulence 
and burnout in the bed, while the overfire air changes 
opposite to the bed air change to control constant total

would have the opposite effect. The operator must, 
therefore, bias the set point based on combustion

flow and air/FGR flow limits to the bed to ensure that 
there is enough air to sustain the combustion process 
while not under or over fluidizing the bed. Fuel sizing 
variations, moisture content, and higher heating value

4.	 	Bed material flow — material flow to the primary 
zone is through makeup and bed drains. These are 
generally intermittent devices, so the operator must 
observe trends in height and temperature, and make 
appropriate adjustments. Most BFB boilers have a 
bed material reclaim system. This system screens 
the bed material that is drained from the boiler and 
reclaims the properly sized material while removing 
agglomerations and tramp material.
Fuel sizing  Careful attention to fuel sizing (minimum 
and maximum) is critical to successful unit operation for 
both under-bed and over-bed feed systems. Finer particles 
are elutriated too quickly and coarser particles tend to 
take too long to burn completely. In either case, UBC and 
SO2 emissions (if being controlled) both increase. Finer 
particles increase NOx emissions and bed temperature 
because the fuel is burning in suspension. An optimum 
size range exists for each fluidized-bed system and fuel 
type. The proper size range is fine tuned through unit 
operating practice. In addition, for the over-bed feed 
system, fuel size interacts with screw speed, angle of 
injection, and furnace gas velocity.
Startup and shutdown considerations  Hot and cold 
startups are determined by the temperature of the bed. 
If the bed is above the minimum ignition temperature, 
then a hot restart can be performed. If the bed is below 
the minimum ignition temperature, a cold startup is 
required. In accordance with the latest applicable NFPA 
Codes, a boiler purge must occur prior to a cold startup 
and after a shutdown. A hot restart does not require a 
purge.
The four main steps of a cold startup are: 1) performing 
a pre-operational checkout, 2) purging the boiler, 3) 
starting the burners (startup burners and load burners if 
applicable), and 4) firing with solid fuel. Prior to starting 
up the boiler, the bubble caps must be covered with bed 
material to prevent overheating. The bed height, when 
slumped and prior to startup, should be 24 in. (610 mm) 
above the bubble caps. As with any boiler during startup, 
the boiler metal temperature curve must be within the 
heatup rate allowed for the boiler pressure parts.
The startup burners are used to bring the bed 
temperature up to the minimum ignition temperature 
so that solid fuel can be introduced. Once solid fuel is 
combusting properly in the bed and the bed temperature is 
above the low-alarm set point, the startup burners can be 
taken out of service. The boiler load can then be increased 
until MCR is reached. However, the rate of increase must 
be controlled to maintain a stable bed temperature.
During normal shutdown, the boiler is brought to a 
minimum load. At that point, there are two options: 1) 
quickly cool the boiler to prepare it for an extended offline 
period, or 2) completely isolate the boiler for a shorter 
downtime. In both cases the boiler must be purged to 
remove all volatiles from the furnace and to burn all 
remaining fuel in the bed. Once the purge is complete, 
the fans can remain running until the unit is sufficiently 
cooled (option 1) or the fans can be tripped while closing 
the dampers to conserve the temperature of the bed and 
refractory (option 2).
Operation of Cyclone Furnaces
B&W originally designed and supplied steam 
generators with Cyclone furnaces to fire low ash fusion 
temperature bituminous coals in a steam generator 
for greater steam flow at higher pressures and steam 
temperatures. At the time, its design also addressed 
the need to significantly reduce particulate stack 
emissions by removing most of the ash from the bottom 
of the furnace as cooled granular ash with almost no 
unburned carbon. The Cyclone furnace in this boiler is 
a water-cooled chamber designed to burn crushed coal. 
The basic design, sizing and general operation of Cyclone 
furnaces are covered in Chapter 15. The key feature that 
affects operations is the collection of most of the coal 
ash as a liquid slag in the Cyclone chamber. This slag 
is continuously tapped into the main furnace through a 
hole at the discharge end of the Cyclone barrel. The slag 
collects on the furnace floor and flows through a tap into 
a water filled tank where the chilling effect of the water 
leaves the slag in granular form. Unique operational 
issues center upon maintaining desired furnace slag 
tapping without excessive maintenance.

Combustion air
All Cyclone furnaces use heated air at a high static 
pressure. The air temperature ranges from 500 to 750F 
(260 to 399C), depending on the unit design and the rank 
of the fuel. The static differential across the Cyclone 
(pressure drop as measured from the upstream side of the 
secondary air compartment damper, or velocity damper, 
to the main furnace pressure) ranges from 32 to 50 in. 
wg (8 to 12.5 kPa). This high pressure produces the very 
high velocities which, in turn, produce the scrubbing 
action required for complete combustion of the crushed 
coal while retaining it within the Cyclone barrel.
A key variable in Cyclone operation is excess air. For 
bituminous coals, which are generally high in sulfur 
and iron content, 10 to 14% excess air is recommended 
at full load operation. This can be reduced to 6 to 8% on 
some eastern bituminous coals with well managed air 
flow controls. Operation at lower excess air can promote 
an oxygen-deficient reducing atmosphere, which can 
significantly increase unit maintenance on higher 
iron content coals. Operation with molten slag under 
substoichiometric conditions can result in iron sulfide 
attack (corrosion) of the Cyclone tubes. When operated 
with insufficient excess air, fuels with high iron content 
can smelt the iron from the ash. A pig iron, which forms a 
strong bond to the boiler tubing, can form and may result 
in tube damage during deposit removal.
Operation with high levels of excess air leads to lower 
thermal efficiency and results in Cyclone cooling. This 
hinders slag tapping. On units with multiple Cyclone 
furnaces, it is important to accurately measure the 
secondary air and coal flow to ensure that each Cyclone 
is operating with the proper air-fuel ratio. Because proper 
excess air is essential, theoretical air curves should be 
used to readjust the excess air levels when individual 
Cyclone furnaces are removed from service.
Firing subbituminous coals is generally more difficult 
for two basic reasons: 1) the fuel is generally higher in 
moisture content which must be evaporated leading to 
reduced heat available for maintaining molten slag, 
and 2) the ash fusion temperature of the coal is more 
temperature sensitive which results in tighter operating 
margins for acceptable slag flow. Units designed for 
subbituminous coal firing have provisions for higher 
primary and secondary air temperature and are generally 
run with 10 to 12% excess air.
Due to environmental concerns, some bituminous 
coal-fired Cyclone furnaces have been converted to 
burn low sulfur subbituminous coal or coal blends. 
Subbituminous coal may have lower ash content than 
most bituminous coals. As a result, less slag is available 
to trap the raw coal particles. This, combined with the 
depressed flame temperature caused by the increased 
moisture content, can result in less coal being entrapped 
in the slag where the combustion is completed. Thus, when 
firing subbituminous coal, it is suggested that the coal 
fineness be increased to 99% passing through a number 
4 standard U.S. sieve compared to 95% for harder to burn 
bituminous coal.
Because the Cyclone furnace is designed to operate 
at a high temperature of combustion in the presence of 
excess air, it is a high producer of NOx emissions. Acting 
on the additional environmental concerns, owners have 
installed OFA systems for combustion NOx control. While 
furnace wall corrosion remains a concern, worthwhile 
NOx reductions have been attained with fuel-rich 
stoichiometry and lower sulfur fuels. Typically, units 
that have been retrofitted with OFA systems operate at 
slightly higher overall excess air levels as compared to 
the baseline levels previously identified. To achieve lower 
NOx emissions, SCR systems can be installed.
When firing higher moisture subbituminous coal, it is 
also preferred to use higher transport air temperatures.
As the moisture content reaches the 20% range at 
design Cyclone fuel inputs, clinkering and UBC in the 
Cyclone and on the furnace floor can increase dramati­
cally. Levels of unburned carbon also increase in the ash 
in the economizer, air heater and precipitator hoppers. 
Supplemental firing with fuel oil or natural gas along 
with design changes may be required if the unit was not 
originally designed for this condition.

Operation of Kraft Recovery Boilers
Overview
The Kraft recovery boiler’s main purpose in the 
pulping process is to reduce the sulfate compounds to 
reusable sodium sulfide for the cooking of the wood 
chips in the digester to make pulp for the production of 
paper products. Through this process, the chemicals are 
recovered to reduce costs and protect the environment.
Along with the recovery of chemicals, the recovery 
boiler has two additional purposes: 1) to efficiently 
recover heat from burning the liquor to generate steam 
for process use, and 2) to operate in an environmentally 
responsible manner, cooling the combustion gases to 
allow particulate collection and minimize the discharge 
of objectionable gases.
Unlike conventional power boilers and other types of 
heat recovery processes, the Kraft (black liquor) boiler is 
not designed to mix the combustion portion of the fuel with 
combustion air in the primary portion of the furnace for 
complete combustion. It is designed to dry the moisture 
from the fuel and provide enough heat to facilitate the 
reduction of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) to sodium sulfide 
(Na2S).
Steam flows from large recovery boilers can exceed 
1,000,000 lb/h (126 kg/s) at superheater outlet pressures 
as high as 1550 psi (10.7 MPa) and final steam tempera­
tures of up to 950F (510C). These units burn black liquor 
with solids contents up to 80% and with heating values 
at about 5500 to 6600 Btu/lb (12,793 to 15,352 kJ/kg). A 
detailed review of designs and general operating practice 
is provided in Chapter 28. Selected operating issues are:
1.	 	black liquor combustion process and air flow,
2.	 	auxiliary burners,
3.	 	operating problems, and
4.	 	smelt-water reactions.
Black liquor combustion process and air flow
Unlike the firing of conventional fossil fuels, recovery 
boiler combustion goes through several distinct stages. 
Black liquor firing is composed of drying, volatile burn­
ing, volatilization of the fixed carbon (char), and smelt 
coalescence. This has a distinct impact on unit operation 
and air addition. All modern B&W recovery boilers are 
equipped with three levels of combustion air. These are 
known as the primary, secondary and tertiary air streams 
in order of increasing elevation in the furnace. Additional 
combustion air levels can be added individually or in 
combination, including more levels of tertiary air for NOx 
reduction, and a liquor air level adjacent to the liquor 
sprays for particulate reduction when burning higher 
solids liquor. (See Chapter 28.)
Primary air  Primary air is in the lowest zone in a 
recovery boiler furnace. The air ports are located ap­
proximately 3 ft (0.9 m) above the furnace floor. Admitted 
on all four walls of the boiler, the primary air provides 
perimeter air around the bed at low velocity and low 
penetration, so the boiler does not lose continuous ignition 
of combustion. The primary air is critical to bed stability, 
bed temperature and reduction efficiency. Primary air 
should be sufficient to burn the volatiles and heat the char 
so that it will begin to volatilize and self ignite and draw 
its oxygen from the surrounding salt cake (Na2SO4). The 
heat released when this part of the elemental carbon is 
burned will then give heat to the surrounding char and 
salt cake to allow the reduction process to take place in the 
bottom of the furnace and in the char bed by conduction 
of heat and distillation burning.
Primary air velocity and distribution is vital for 
optimum bed stability. A required quantity of primary 
air flow with sufficient momentum is introduced to the 
furnace hearth to promote adequate bed temperature 
for chemical reduction. The required primary air flow is 
based on the liquor properties which affect the desired 
liquor spray characteristics required for a particular 
furnace and include droplet size, droplet velocity and 
spray distribution.
Secondary air  High pressure secondary air on newer 
units is designed to penetrate the full cross-section of the 
unit. On older units with numerous, small secondary 
air ports on all four walls, the jet penetration will be 
limited. It is admitted at approximately 8 ft (2.4 m) 
above the furnace floor for combustion air to ignite the 
CO gas coming off of the char burning in the lower bed. 
This releases heat to this zone of the furnace to dry black 
liquor droplets and support pyrolysis (or volatile burning).
Experience gained from numerical modeling and 
operating trials has shown that a single level of secondary 
air introduced in an interlaced pattern approximately 
10 ft (3.1 m) below the liquor guns and about 4 ft (1.2 
m) above the primary air ports provides the optimum 
use of secondary air to support combustion. Optimum 
jet penetration from each of the ports is controlled by a 
velocity damper. This arrangement promotes the proper 
drying of the liquor through combustion of the pyrolysis 
gases without interference from the secondary air jets 
and prepares the material reaching the hearth to interact 
with primary air for maximum chemical reduction.
A properly adjusted recovery boiler will maintain bed 
size by the proper drying of liquor falling to the hearth 
through the secondary air jets. The formation of a large 
bed where the secondary air jets are directly impacting 
bed material is not desirable and is an indication of 
inadequate hearth and char temperature. In some cases 
a bed can become so unstable that combustion ceases to 
be self-sustaining resulting in sticky, hard regions of the 
bed that are no longer active. This can lead to a blackout 
condition when the inactive areas become large enough. 
This condition can be confirmed by a sharp drop in steam 
generation. The operator may find it necessary to add 
auxiliary fuel firing, stop liquor firing, and burn out the 
unacceptable bed material to regain control of the hearth 
conditions before attempting to resume black liquor firing.

Tertiary air  All recovery boilers provide between 50 
to 90% of total combustion air to the ports that are located 
below the liquor spray nozzle level. The remaining air 
required to complete the oxidation of sulfur compounds 
and CO is introduced at one or more air levels above the 
liquor spray nozzles. The elevation of these tertiary ports 
is approximately 10 ft (3.1 m) above the liquor spray nozzle 
elevation to avoid interference and entrainment of the 
liquor sprays which can cause carryover.
In some cases, two levels of vertically aligned tertiary 
ports are utilized to take advantage of the reinforcing 
effect of air jets in that closely spaced arrangement. The 
tertiary port sizing is set by similar criteria used for the 
secondary air ports. The tertiary air jet is intended to 
penetrate the full cross-section of the unit through the 
momentum of the upward moving gas stream from the 
combustion in the hearth at the primary and secondary 
air levels. Like the secondary ports, the tertiary ports are 
arranged in a horizontally interlaced pattern and have 
velocity dampers to provide adjustment for optimum jet 
penetration. They usually operate at slightly higher static 
pressure than secondary ports to achieve the necessary 
performance. To maintain combustion in the proper loca­
tion, the air flow splits and pressures must be effectively 
maintained. Ranges of typical air flow distributions, inlet

Multilevel tertiary air  In some cases, particularly 
on existing units with tertiary ports already present, a 
fourth level of air is used to reduce NOx emissions. By 
delaying the introduction of the final quantity of total air 
required for complete combustion, a significant reduction 
in NOx emissions can be achieved. The final level of air 
ports may be as much as 25 ft (7.6 m) above the liquor 
spray nozzle elevation. Air ports for this fourth level are 
designed with similar criteria as tertiary ports, equipped 
with velocity dampers, and arranged in an interlaced 
pattern intended to penetrate the cross-section of the unit.
Optimum NOx reduction does not require both a 
dedicated third and fourth level of air ports. The benefit 
of lower NOx emissions can also be achieved by utilizing 
a single, final level of air ports (tertiary). Port elevation 
selection ultimately depends on accessibility, adequate 
furnace height and clearance to the nose arch or screen, 
and the relative NOx reduction that is required.
Liquor guns  Successful stationary or oscillating 
firing depends on the correct liquor droplet size. This 
size must permit complete in-flight drying before reach­
ing the bed. The variables in black liquor combustion 
include liquor percent solids, temperature and pressure 
at the spray nozzles, spray nozzle sizing and splash plate 
angle, and number and position of black liquor guns in 
service. Other variables include the vertical and angular 
movement of the oscillators or the off-horizontal angle of 
the liquor guns for stationary firing. Other factors on the 
air side include total excess air, air temperature(s), air 
splits between the primary, secondary and tertiary ports, 
and the static air pressure in each of these air zones.
The objective in the manipulation of all of these 
variables is to control the steps of the drying and combus­
tion of the liquor, and to control bed temperatures. A 
comprehensive discussion of recovery boiler design and 
emissions is provided in Chapter 28.
Auxiliary burners
Recovery boilers are equipped with oil- and/or natural 
gas-fired auxiliary burners located at the secondary and 
tertiary air port elevations. The burners in the secondary 
windboxes are used for unit startup, as black liquor can 
only be fired into a heated furnace with an auxiliary 
ignition source. The secondary burners are also used to 
stabilize the smelt flow and bed ignition during an upset 
condition and to burn the bed out of the unit on shutdown.
